hints_html:
If you want to avoid the fractions in the matrix \(A\), you can determine the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the matrix \(B= 10A\).

The eigenvector of \(B\) and \(A\) are the same, while the eigenvalues of \(B\) are ten times the eigenvalues of \(A\).

Once you compute the eigenvalues \(\lambda_1, \lambda_2\) and eigenvectors \(v_1, v_2\), you can write \(x_0\) as \(x_0 = av_1 + bv_2\) for some \(a,b\in\mathbb{R}\). How does that help to compute \(x_n\)?

The eigenvector of $B$ and $A$ are the same, while the eigenvalues of
$B$ are ten times the eigenvalues of $A$.

Once you compute the eigenvalues $\lambda_1, \lambda_2$ and eigenvectors
$v_1, v_2$, you can write $x_0$ as $x_0 = av_1 + bv_2$ for some
$a,b\in\mathbb{R}$. How does that help to compute $x_n$?
hints_raw:
If you want to avoid the fractions in the matrix <math> \ A</math>, you can determine the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the matrix <math>\ B= 10A</math>.

The eigenvector of <math>\ B</math> and <math>\ A</math> are the same, while the eigenvalues of <math>\ B</math> are ten times the eigenvalues of <math>\ A</math>.
Once you compute the eigenvalues <math>\ \lambda_1, \lambda_2</math> and eigenvectors <math>\ v_1, v_2</math>, you can write <math>\ x_0</math> as <math>\ x_0 = av_1 + bv_2</math> for some <math>a,b\in\mathbb{R}</math>. How does that help to compute <math>\ x_n</math>?
sols_html:
Determine eigenvalues of \(B=10A\)

We will first find the eigenvalues of the matrix \(B=\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 8 & 5 \\ 2 & 5 \end{array} \right]\) to avoid dealing with fractions. The eigenvalues of the matrix A, will simply be \(\frac{1}{10}\) of this integer matrix B.

To find the eigenvalues we calculate as usual:

\[\begin{aligned} \det\left( \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 8-t & 5 \\ 2 & 5-t \end{array} \right] \right) &=(8-t)(5-t) - (5)(2) \\ &= t^2 - 13t + 30\\ &= (t-3)(t-10)\\ &=0\end{aligned}\]

Determine eigenvectors of \(B=10A\)

For the eigenvectors with eigenvalue 3 we look at \(\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 8-3 & 5 \\ 2 & 5-3 \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 5 & 5 \\ 2 & 2 \end{array} \right]\) which gives the eigenvector \(\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 \\ -1 \end{array} \right]\).

For the eigenvalue 10, we look at the \(\left[ \begin{array}{cc} -2 & 5 \\ 2 & -5 \end{array} \right]\) which gives the eigenvectors \(\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 5 \\ 2 \end{array} \right]\).

Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of \(A\)

For the matrix A this means that A has the

  • eigenvalue \(\frac{3}{10}\) with eigenvector v_1=\left[ \begin{array}{cc}

1 \\ -1 \end{array} \right]

  • eigenvalue \(1\) with eigenvector v_2=\left[ \begin{array}{cc}

5 \\ 2 \end{array} \right]

Find \(a,b\in\mathbb{R}\) such that \(x_0 = av_1+bv_2\)

To find the closed formulae for the components of xn we decompose the vector \(x_0\) into a sum of the eigenvectors of A. To do so, we use the extended matrix:

\[\begin{aligned} [v_1 \ v_2\ |\ x_0] = \left[ \begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 5 & 4 \\ -1 & 2 & 1 \\ \end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 5 & 4 \\ 0 & 7 & 5 \\ \end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 0 & 3/7 \\ 0 & 1 & 5/7 \\ \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]

Thus a = 3/7 and b = 5/7 and therefore

\[\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 4 \\ 1 \end{array} \right] = 3/7 \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 \\ -1 \end{array} \right] + 5/7\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 5 \\ 2 \end{array} \right].\end{aligned}\]

’ Computing \(x_n\)’

We can now compute \(x_n\) as follows:

\[\begin{aligned} x_n = A^nx_0 &= A^n\left(\frac{3}{7} \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 \\ -1 \end{array} \right] + \frac{5}{7}\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 5 \\ 2 \end{array} \right]\right) \\&= \frac{3}{7} A^n\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 \\ -1 \end{array} \right] + \frac{5}{7}A^n\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 5 \\ 2 \end{array} \right] \\ &= \frac{3}{7}\frac{3^n}{10^n} \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 \\ -1 \end{array} \right] + \frac{5}{7}1^n\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 5 \\ 2 \end{array} \right] \end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
'''Determine eigenvalues of <math>\ B=10A</math>'''

We will first find the eigenvalues of the matrix <math>B=\left[ \begin{array}{cc}
8 & 5  \\ 
2 & 5
\end{array} \right]  </math> to avoid dealing with fractions. The eigenvalues of the matrix ''A'', will simply be <math> \frac{1}{10}</math> of this integer matrix ''B''.

To find the eigenvalues we calculate as usual:

:<math> 
\begin{align}
\det\left( \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
8-t & 5  \\ 
2 & 5-t
\end{array} \right]  \right) &=(8-t)(5-t) - (5)(2) \\
 &= t^2 - 13t + 30\\
&= (t-3)(t-10)\\
&=0
\end{align} 
</math> 

'''Determine eigenvectors of <math>\ B=10A</math>'''

For the eigenvectors with '''eigenvalue 3''' we look at <math> \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
8-3 & 5  \\ 
2 & 5-3
\end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
5 & 5  \\ 
2 & 2
\end{array} \right] </math> which gives the eigenvector <math> \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
1 \\ 
-1 
\end{array} \right] </math>. 

For the '''eigenvalue 10''', we look at the <math> \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
-2 & 5  \\ 
2 & -5
\end{array} \right] </math> which gives the eigenvectors <math> \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
5 \\ 
2 
\end{array} \right] </math>.


'''Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of <math>\ A</math>'''

For the matrix ''A'' this means that ''A'' has the
* eigenvalue <math> \frac{3}{10}</math> with eigenvector <math> v_1=\left[ \begin{array}{cc}
1 \\ 
-1 
\end{array} \right] </math>
* eigenvalue <math>\ 1</math> with eigenvector <math> v_2=\left[ \begin{array}{cc}
5 \\ 
2 
\end{array} \right] </math>



'''Find <math>\ a,b\in\mathbb{R}</math> such that <math>\ x_0 = av_1+bv_2</math>'''

To find the closed formulae for the components of '''x'''<sub>n</sub> we decompose the vector <math> x_0 </math> into a sum of the eigenvectors of ''A''. To do so, we use the extended matrix:

:<math> [v_1 \  v_2\ |\ x_0] =  \left[ \begin{array}{cc|c}
1 & 5 & 4 \\ 
-1 & 2 & 1 \\ 
\end{array} \right]  \sim \left[ \begin{array}{cc|c}
1 & 5 & 4 \\ 
0 & 7 & 5 \\ 
\end{array} \right] \sim \left[ \begin{array}{cc|c}
1 & 0 & 3/7 \\ 
0 & 1 & 5/7 \\ 
\end{array} \right] </math> 

Thus ''a'' = 3/7 and ''b'' = 5/7 and therefore
:<math> \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
4 \\ 
1 
\end{array} \right]  = 3/7 \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
1 \\ 
-1 
\end{array} \right]  + 5/7\left[ \begin{array}{cc}
5 \\ 
2 
\end{array} \right] </math>.




''' Computing <math>\ x_n</math>'''

We can now compute <math> x_n</math> as follows:

<math>
\begin{align}
 x_n = A^nx_0 &= A^n\left(\frac{3}{7} \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
1 \\ 
-1 
\end{array} \right]  + \frac{5}{7}\left[ \begin{array}{cc}
5 \\ 
2 
\end{array} \right]\right) \\&= \frac{3}{7} A^n\left[ \begin{array}{cc}
1 \\ 
-1 
\end{array} \right]  + \frac{5}{7}A^n\left[ \begin{array}{cc}
5 \\ 
2 
\end{array} \right]  \\ &= \frac{3}{7}\frac{3^n}{10^n} \left[ \begin{array}{cc}
1 \\ 
-1 
\end{array} \right]  + \frac{5}{7}1^n\left[ \begin{array}{cc}
5 \\ 
2 
\end{array} \right] 
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
Given the discrete dynamical system xn+1 = Axn with

\[\begin{aligned} A = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 0.8 & 0.5 \\ 0.2 & 0.5 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the system. Then find closed formulae for the components of xn with the initial value \(\mathbf{x}_0 = \left[\begin{array}{c} 4 \\ 1 \end{array}\right]\)
statement_latex:
Given the discrete dynamical system
\textbf{\emph{x\textbf{\textsubscript{n+1} = A}x}}\textsubscript{n} with

\begin{align*}
A = \left[\begin{array}{cc}
0.8 & 0.5 \\ 0.2 & 0.5
\end{array}\right]
\end{align*}

Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the system. Then find closed
formulae for the components of \textbf{x}\textsubscript{n} with the
initial value
$\mathbf{x}_0 = \left[\begin{array}{c} 4 \\ 1 \end{array}\right]$
statement_raw:
Given the discrete dynamical system '''''x'''<sub>n+1</sub> = A'''x'''''<sub>n</sub> with

:<math>
A = \left[\begin{array}{cc}
0.8 & 0.5 \\ 0.2 & 0.5
\end{array}\right]
</math>

Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the system. Then find closed formulae for the components of '''x'''<sub>n</sub> with the initial value <math> \mathbf{x}_0 = \left[\begin{array}{c} 4 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] </math>
